title: 106_s382
content: The Act titled "Minuteman Missile National Historic Site Establishment Act of 1999" is established for the purpose of preserving historical sites related to the Minuteman Missile. Congress finds that the Minuteman II intercontinental ballistic missile launch control facility and launch facility known as "Delta 1" and "Delta 9" have national significance as the best preserved examples of American history during the Cold War. These facilities symbolize the dedication and preparedness of Air Force missileers stationed in remote locations during that era. The Minuteman II missile defense system facilities represent the history and significance of the Cold War, arms race, and ICBM development. The National Park System lacks a unit dedicated to commemorating the Cold War. This Act aims to preserve and interpret the structures associated with the Minuteman II system and highlight its historical role in America's strategic commitment to world peace. The Act aims to preserve and interpret structures related to the Minuteman II missile defense system in the context of the Cold War and America's commitment to world peace. SEC. 3. MINUTEMAN MISSILE NATIONAL HISTORIC SITE. The Minuteman Missile National Historic Site is established in South Dakota as a unit of the National Park System, consisting of the Minuteman II ICBM launch control facilities. The Minuteman Missile National Historic Site includes the Delta 1 Launch Control Facility and the Delta 9 Launch Facility. The map of the site is available for public inspection. The Secretary of the Interior can make minor boundary adjustments. The site is administered in accordance with the Act and laws. The Minuteman Missile National Historic Site is administered in accordance with the Act and laws applicable to the National Park System, including coordination with other agencies like the Secretary of Defense and the Secretary of State. The Secretary may consult with the Secretary of Defense and the Secretary of State to ensure compliance with treaties for the historic site. The Secretary can also enter cooperative agreements with public and private entities, acquire land through donation, purchase, exchange, or transfer from other Federal agencies, with some prohibited acquisitions. The Secretary is prohibited from acquiring contaminated land under the Act unless all necessary remedial actions have been taken. Additionally, the Secretary can only acquire land owned by the State of South Dakota under certain conditions. The Secretary must prepare a general management plan for a historic site within 3 years of funds being available. The plan should evaluate suitable locations for visitor and administrative facilities within designated areas on the map. The Secretary will determine the location for visitor and administrative facilities at the historic site, modifying the site boundary accordingly. Coordination with Badlands National Park for administrative functions will be considered in the plan development. Authorization of appropriations for the development of visitor and administrative facilities at the historic site. Authorization of appropriations for the development of visitor and administrative facilities at the historic site. Funds from the Air Force in fiscal year 1999 will be transferred for the maintenance and operation of the historic site. The Legacy Resource Management Program funds are not affected by this Act. The Act affects funds for the Legacy Resource Management Program of the Air Force previously designated for resource preservation and treaty compliance.
